document.docAuthor: González, María E., Grismado, Cristian J. & Ramírez, Martín J.
document.docTitle: Meriola macrocephala González & Grismado & Ramírez 2021, comb. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A Taxonomic Revision Of The Spider Genus Meriola Banks (Araneae: Trachelidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A Taxonomic Revision Of The Spider Genus Meriola Banks (Araneae: Trachelidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Clubiona macrocephala
Nicolet, 1849: 448
(two male and two female syntypes from Chile , Valdivia , in MNHN 6994, labeled as “ Trachel. megacephalus ”, examined; Fig. 48 a–f).

Trachelopachys macrocephalus Simon, 1897: 185
;
Platnick, 1975: 10
,
Platnick & Ewing, 1995: 7

subSubSection.paragraph:
Cetonana barrosi Mello-Leit
„o, 1951: 337, figs 11–12 (female holotype from Maullin , Llanquihue , Región de los Lagos , Chile , formerly in MNRJ, probably lost; examined by Platnick & Ewing, 1995 ). syn. nov.

treatmentCitationGroup.paragraph: Diagnosis. Males ( Figs 5 d–f, 47a–f, 48) are easily distinguished by the long embolus that coils on the distal half of the bulb. Females ( Figs 5 a–c, 46, 47g) are recognized by the paired anterior hoods and the large, circular median field flanked by semicircular ridges, with the elongated copulatory ducts visible through the cuticle.

FIGURE 44.
Meriola longitarsis Simon.
a , male habitus, dorsal view (MACN-Ar 30880); b , same, ventral view; c , same, lateral view; d , prosoma, dorsal view; e , same, ventral view; f , same, lateral view. g , female alive (MACN-Ar 40964).

FIGURE 45.
Meriola longitarsis Simon
, male. a , habitus, anterior view (MACN-Ar 30880); b , male holotype, habitus, lateral view (MNHN 12913). c , holotype, specimen labels. d , left palp, prolateral view (MACN-Ar 30880); e , same, ventral view; f , same, retrolateral view. g , left palp of holotype, prolateral view; h , same, ventral view; i , same, retrolateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Note. The type material of
Clubiona macrocephala Nicolet, 1849
was considered a nomen dubium by Platnick & Ewing (1995) , since the types were presumed lost (see Ramírez 1989 ). Simon (1897) synonymized
C. obliterata Nicolet, 1849
and
C. ultima Nicolet, 1849
with
C. macrocephala
and transferred that species to
Trachelopachys
. One of us (CJG) found some of Nicolet’s specimens in MNHN, labeled as “ Trachel. megacephalus ” (written by Simon, Fig. 48 a–f); by virtue of the correspondence with the description, and by the similarity of the terms “macrocephalus” and “megacephalus”, we consider highly probable that Simon wrongly transcribed the label of the specimens. Since the types of
C. obliterata
and
C. ultima
are still missing, we regard these as nomina dubia , as suggested by Platnick & Ewing (1995) .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 47.
Meriola macrocephala (Nicolet)
comb. nov.
. a , male habitus, dorsal view (MACN-Ar 29256); b , same, ventral view; c , same, lateral view; d , prosoma, dorsal view; e , same, ventral view; f , same, lateral view. g , female alive (MACN-Ar MJR-2774).

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. See Platnick & Ewing (1995) for male and female descriptions.

Natural history and habitat. Several specimens were collected by canopy fogging, in vegetation that reaches up to 50 m in height. In addition, specimens were collected in shrubs by beating or hand collecting.
Distribution. Known from Chubut , Neuquén and Río Negro provinces in Argentina , and Chile (regions II through XI) ( Fig. 92 ).
